definitions.definition: the middle point or part of something
definitions.sensetop: in the centre of somethingin the centreat the centre of something

examples.text: He walked to the centre of the circle.
There was a long table in the centre of the room.
The statue is in the very centre of the temple.
The brownie should be firm on the outside but soft in the centre.
Aristotle believed that the Earth was at the centre of the universe.
The executive at the centre of the bribery scandal was convicted last week.
chocolates with soft centres

definitions.definition: the main part of a town or city where there are a lot of shops and offices

examples.text: I got a lift into the centre of town.
a town-centre car park
We've bought a flat in the very centre of Cambridge.
I have an apartment in the centre of São Paulo.
a museum in the centre of Birmingham

definitions.definition: a place or an area where a lot of people live; a place where a lot of business or cultural activity takes place

examples.text: major urban/industrial centres
At that time Winchester was still a major centre of population.
The university is a leading centre for scientific research.
Small towns in South India serve as economic and cultural centres for the surrounding villages.
Tokyo is one of the main financial centres of the world.
the economic nerve centre of Germany

definitions.definition: a building or place used for a particular purpose or activity

examples.text: a **shopping/community/health/fitness centre**
The company has recently opened a new **training centre**.
the Centre for Policy Studies
You can use our fully equipped business centre.
They've set up a local centre for people with epilepsy.
The classes are run by the Centre for Languages and Literature.
I had to get a taxi from the hotel to the conference centre.

definitions.definition: a place where a particular kind of work is done extremely well

examples.text: Darlington could become a regional centre of excellence for nursery nurse training.
The university is recognized as an international centre of excellence for training dentists.

definitions.definition: the point towards which people direct their attention

examples.text: She likes to be the **centre of attention**.
The prime minister is at the centre of a political row over leaked Cabinet documents.
She always liked to feel that she was at the centre of things.
He could never doubt that he was the centre of her world.
The captain was at the centre of the action right through the game.

definitions.definition: a moderate (= middle) political position or party, between the extremes of left-wing and right-wing parties

examples.text: a party of the centre
Are her views to the left or right of centre?
a centre party
Politically, she is considered to be slightly left of centre.
a party that occupies the centre ground of British politics

definitions.definition: a player or position in the middle of the pitch, court, etc.
in or into the most important position

examples.text: The issue has moved front and center in his presidential campaign.
He's giving away money left, right and centre.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin centrum, from Greek kentron ‘sharp point, stationary point of a pair of compasses’, related to kentein ‘to prick’.
